intro: Cyrtandra paludosa var. subherbacea, commonly known as the swamp cyrtandra, is a flowering plant native to wetland habitats in tropical and subtropical regions. It is a member of the Gesneriaceae family and is characterized by its herbaceous growth habit and small, showy flowers. The plant typically features opposite, ovate leaves with a smooth or slightly hairy surface. Its flowers are usually pink or white, with five petals and a tubular corolla, adapted for pollination by insects. It thrives in moist, nutrient-poor soils and is often found in marshes, swamps, and along the edges of water bodies.
